description: The Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy header controls whether a browsing context can be shared between different domains. This header is used to mitigate various cross-origin attacks such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) and Cross-Site History Manipulation (CSHM).

response-directives.description: Specifies that the browsing context can only be accessed by pages from the same origin.
response-directives.details: When the Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy header contains the same-origin directive, the browsing context can only be accessed by pages from the same origin. This is the default behavior if the header is not specified.

response-directives.description: Specifies that the browsing context can be accessed by pages from the same origin and from pop-up windows.
response-directives.details: When the Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy header contains the same-origin-allow-popups directive, the browsing context can be accessed by pages from the same origin and from pop-up windows. This allows pop-ups to open a new browsing context that can be shared with the parent window.

response-directives.description: Specifies that there are no restrictions on the sharing of the browsing context.
response-directives.details: When the Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy header contains the unsafe-none directive, there are no restrictions on the sharing of the browsing context. This is not recommended as it can expose the browsing context to various cross-origin attacks.
